head.title: Trash of Past Is the Stuff of Archeology

hedline.hl1: Trash of Past Is the Stuff of Archeology

block.p: Adam Hochschild writes of a graveyard in the Northeast eroded by acid rain and a beach in Morocco littered with plastic, and then laments the destruction of our monuments and the durability of our waste (''A Legacy of Ruin,'' Op-Ed, Dec. 7).

When he speculates how posterity will view us, he implies that our knowledge of antiquity is derived from monumental architecture. This is only partly true. The monuments may draw our eyes and spark our imaginations, but it is the rubbish pits and scattered potsherds that speak with the greatest eloquence. Future archeologists will puzzle over rounded grave markers while tracing the limits of our culture by the bits of imperishable plastic we leave behind.

The wide distribution of waste and the destruction of the mementos of past generations is a tragedy that is born of our ignorance and pride. But it only compounds the crime to imply that our civilization is all alone in this regard. WARREN BUCKLES Madison, Wis., Dec. 7, 1987
